content.description:
Generally very good rock throughout with good ledges for belays. It would be difficult to give a detailed  pitch by pitch description but the photos attached should give a good idea as to the route. Below is a rough breakdown of the pitch lengths:

Pitch 1: 25m,  belay second from large slung boulder on good ledge.

Pitch 2: 35m, belay second from small alcove on ledge with good cracks for building anchor.

Pitch 3: 35m, belay second from cracks in steep wall at the base of the next step.

Pitch 4: 35m, belay second from cracks on left of wet section (next pitch crosses wet section and continues up)

Pitch 5: 50m, belay second from slung boulders on grassy ledge.

Pitch 6: 65m, belay second from grassy ledge with scrambling terrain above.

Scramble to top.



Traditional climbing, no fixed gear. Standard rack to BD#4 with doubles in finger and hand sizes.


Park at the trailhead for the Tablelands hike and follow trail to the lookout platform. Continue into Winter House Gorge to the large wall near the back on the western side.

climbs.name: Sounds Gouda
climbs.fa: Liam Bennett, Kenny Tuach, David Bruneau, Ania Polak

content.description:
A nice climb with an alpine feel along an exposed ridge.

P1: climb up an arete with cracks to big ledge, then go up a steep offwidth crack and exit right to belay below a nice diagonal hand crack. 100 ft, 5.7

P2: climb the diagonal hand crack , then ramble along ridge up easier slabs to a belay on a nice ridge flat ridge below a steeper ridge - 100 ft, 5.4 

P3: climb left side of the steep ridge until you can step to the right side, then follow good cracks up to belay -100 ft, 5.7 

P4: walk left around a pile of boulders in front of the belay to a nice slab, climb up the right side of the slab with some finger cracks, then walk along ridge until you find a good belay -150 ft, 5.6 

P5: walk up to the bird-shaped gendarme, then climb most of the way up the back of the gendarme to continue along the ridge (optionally tagging the top of the gendarme for a nice photo op) then continue along the blocky ridge to a belay at some boulders that block the view of the last pitch - 200ft, low 5th 

P6: 100ft of scrambling along ridge to an obvious splitter crack up the final steep section, climb the slick crack to the summit - 200ft, 5.7

Follows the ridge in the middle of an obvious, stepped buttress 
Standard rack to 5", gear belays

Great moderate climbing! Difficult to describe as there are many options but the route generally climbs straight-up from the beginning pitch (pictured), along the best looking rock. 

The descent is along the top of the plateau to the northwest, then down either the west, or east side of the large, north-facing bowl (see photo).



Winter House Brook Gorge.

Hike along the Tablelands trail to the viewing platform located in Winterhouse Brook Gorge. Continue into the gorge, heading for a waterfall coming down the center of the western wall (east aspect). The route begins in a corner next to the base of the waterfall (pictured).

Double rack up to BD#2 (#3 is also recommended)

The route ends up on the right of the big V feature spanning a third of the cliff height, with pitch 5 slab being the absolute highlight. There is a significant rockfall potential throughout, so watch for loose rocks and protect your belay.



Pitch 1 - 65m - 5.5/6 - Start up a short dihedral with good pro just to the right of the dark coloured gully on fairly low angle terrain. Trend slightly right and up through blocky terrain and continue back left along a broad, shallow-angled ridge. Step down and to the right to boulders at the top of a loose gully. Sling the “necks” where the boulders contact each other for a belay anchor.



Pitch 2 - 60m - 4th class - Scramble up to the top of the gully on low angle rock, avoiding scree to belay at the wall on the right side.

Pitch 3 - 65m - 5.7R - Start pitch on the right side of the gully, climbing up on marginal sparse protection trending right and then back left to the left side of a 5-6m pinnacle feature and sling the boulder sitting on/above it for an anchor.

Pitch 4 - 25m - 5.8 - Move up for a few feet before making a committing traverse left onto a good ledge at the base of the upper face. Continue left along ledge towards the corner and construct anchor where suitable protection can be found (The first ascensionists placed the anchor pieces about 3m above the ledge and extended the anchor).

Pitch 5 - 60m - 5.8 - Head straight up from the belay through fun sustained climbing with great protection to a ramp. Walk right on the ramp and then up left to climb the short ledgey section and top out to sling a boulder for belay. 



Park at the trailhead for the Tablelands hike and follow trail to the lookout platform. Continue into Winter House Gorge and follow river until below the left hand side of the large wall near the back on the western side. Approach wall and scramble around right to top of short bench to reach ledge at base of route.

Traditional climbing, no fixed gear. Gear anchors and slung boulders

The alien landscape of the Tablelands has some decent multipitch rock routes with an alpine feel. There are many potential lines, though I only know of 3 existing routes.  
  
 The strange, peridotite rock has many protectable cracks and is quite solid, but seems to have very low friction. I found that cams can slide out in parallel cracks, similar to limestone, so placing cams in pods and using passive pro is advised.
